docs.lead_paragraph: The budget projections showing a deficit of $9 trillion over the next decade are worrying, but the real concern is how the nation’s politicians deal with the debt.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite what he called ''the hubbub'' this month about end-of-life health care, Senator Mark Warner devoted a town meeting to the topic on Thursday. It was actually civil. Mr. Warner, Democrat of Virginia, drew a sympathetic audience that included ministers, priests, rabbis, hospice workers, a physician and several constituents who on Tuesday night had attended a local congressman's larger meeting that was disrupted by anti-euthanasia activists.
docs.abstract: Sen Mark Warner devotes town meeting to topic of end-of-life health care, drawing sympathetic audience; calls usage of term 'death panels' ignorant effort to frighten people; warns proposed incentives for living wills are in danger of being dropped from legislation (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Times Square may not be anybody's idea of a town hall. But it will serve as the setting Saturday for Democratic and health-related groups that support President Obama's goals for overhauling the health care system. More than 75 groups plan to march from various locales and converge at Times Square for a rally at 2 p.m.
docs.abstract: More than 75 Democratic and health-related groups that support Pres Obama's health care system overhaul plan to march from various locales and converge at Times Square for rally; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael S. Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, seems to be ambivalent about Medicare. In an op-ed column in The Washington Post on Monday, announcing a Seniors' Health Care Bill of Rights, Mr. Steele wrote that his party wanted ''to protect Medicare and not cut it in the name of 'health insurance reform.' ''
docs.abstract: Republican National Committee Chmn Michael S Steele expresses contradictory opinions about Mecicare cuts; writes in Washington Post Op-Ed article that he is against Medicare cuts in name of health insurance reform but in NPR interview, says he supports making some cuts; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Michael S. Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, seems to be ambivalent about Medicare.      In an op-ed column in The Washington Post on Monday, announcing a Seniors' Health Care Bill of Rights, Mr. Steele wrote that his party...

docs.lead_paragraph: Amid speculation about what a health care overhaul might mean for Medicare, what do the people who actually run the program have to say? Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius, whose purview includes the federal Medicare program, sought to allay the concerns of older Americans on Thursday, issuing a report subtitled ''Protecting Coverage and Strengthening Medicare.''
docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Sec Kathleen Sebelius seeks to allay concerns of older Americans worried about what health care overhaul might mean for Medicare; issues report describing how proposals being discussed in Washington will benefit seniors; photo (S)
